problems.scenario:
JAYSON Company reported an unadjusted cash in bank balance of ₱3,500,000 as of December 31, 2023. The following details were provided:

• Customer check of ₱480,000 dated January 2, 2024 was already included in the cash balance.
• Customer check of ₱350,000 dated December 8, 2023 was included in the cash balance even though it is not yet encashed as of December 31, 2023.
• Supplier check of ₱400,000 dated November 30, 2023 was already deducted even though the supplier actually encashed it on January 20, 2024.
• Supplier check of ₱250,000 dated December 28, 2023 was already deducted even though it was given to the supplier only on January 5, 2024.

questions.question: What is the correct adjusted cash balance as of December 31, 2023?
questions.explanation:
Calculation:
Unadjusted balance: ₱3,500,000
Deduct post-dated customer check: -₱480,000 (dated 2024)
Add back supplier check not yet given: +₱250,000 (not released until 2024)
No adjustment needed for properly dated checks
Adjusted balance: ₱3,270,000

journal_entries.description: To adjust for post-dated customer check
To adjust for unreleased supplier check

problems.scenario:
PARALUMAN Company reported cash balance of ₱4,600,000 as of December 31, 2023. The following checks were already recorded:

• A check written for ₱190,000 dated February 28, 2023 is yet to be encashed by the payee.
• A check written for ₱110,000 dated September 28, 2023 is also yet to be encashed by the payee.
• A check written for ₱280,000 dated January 10, 2024 was already in the possession of the payee as of December 31, 2023.
• A check received amounting to ₱360,000 dated January 15, 2024.
• A check received amounting to ₱500,000 dated October 1, 2023.

questions.question: What is the correct adjusted cash balance as of December 31, 2023?
questions.explanation:
Calculation:
Unadjusted balance: ₱4,600,000
Deduct post-dated received check: -₱360,000 (dated 2024)
Add back post-dated written check: +₱280,000 (dated 2024)
Add back stale checks written: +₱190,000 (Feb 2023) and +₱110,000 (Sep 2023)
Note: The October 1, 2023 check received is properly recorded
Adjusted balance: ₱4,680,000

journal_entries.description: To adjust for stale check dated February 28, 2023
To adjust for stale check dated September 28, 2023
To adjust for post-dated check written
To adjust for post-dated check received

problems.scenario:
EDITH Company reported the following information as of December 31, 2023:

• Investment in common shares of another entity amounting to ₱400,000 is expected to be sold next month.
• Three-year treasury bonds amounting to ₱2,000,000 were acquired on the original date of issue.
• Five-year treasury bonds amounting to ₱3,000,000 were acquired on November 15, 2023. Maturity date is on February 1, 2024.
• Redeemable preference shares amounting to ₱1,800,000 were acquired last December 1, 2023. The shares will mature on January 15, 2024.
• Excess funds of ₱3,500,000 were parked to time deposit on July 1, 2023. The certificate indicated a January 12, 2024 maturity date.

questions.question: What is the total amount of cash equivalents?
questions.explanation:
Cash equivalents calculation:
• Common shares (₱400,000) - NOT a cash equivalent (equity instrument)
• 3-year treasury bonds (₱2,000,000) - NOT a cash equivalent (original term > 3 months)
• 5-year treasury bonds (₱3,000,000) - Cash equivalent (near maturity)
• Redeemable preference shares (₱1,800,000) - Cash equivalent (matures within 3 months)
• Time deposit (₱3,500,000) - Cash equivalent (matures within 3 months)
Total cash equivalents = ₱3,000,000 + ₱1,800,000 + ₱3,500,000 = ₱8,300,000

problems.scenario:
As of December 31, 2023, MANDAUE Company reported the following information:

Cash on hand: ₱2,500,000
Checking account 1 - UBP: ₱4,500,000
Checking account 2 - UBP: (₱1,200,000)
Checking account - BPI: (₱700,000)
Savings account - PNB: ₱2,000,000
Savings account - BDO: ₱5,500,000
Commercial papers: ₱1,800,000
Money market placements: ₱1,000,000
Time deposit, 3 months: ₱800,000
Time deposit, 6 months: ₱1,500,000

Additional details:
a. Included in the cash on hand balance is a ₱200,000 customer check dated February 14, 2024.
b. Deducted from checking account 1 - UBP is a ₱300,000 supplier check dated December 20, 2023 that was only given to the payee on January 3, 2024.
c. Deducted from checking account 1 - UBP is a ₱450,000 supplier check dated December 22, 2023 and was given to the payee on the same date, but was encashed only on January 18, 2024.
d. Half of the savings account maintained in BDO is for the purchase of inventories for the next three months while the other half is for the marketing employees' travel fund.
e. The savings account set aside in PNB is for the acquisition of fleet of transportation vehicles for use of its marketing employees.

questions.question: What is the total amount of cash and cash equivalents?
questions.explanation:
Cash calculation:
Cash on hand: ₱2,500,000 - ₱200,000 (post-dated) = ₱2,300,000
Checking UBP net: ₱4,500,000 + ₱300,000 (unreleased) - ₱1,200,000 = ₱3,600,000
Checking BPI: (₱700,000)
Savings BDO: ₱5,500,000 (both inventory and travel fund are not restricted)
Savings PNB: ₱0 (restricted for asset acquisition)

Cash equivalents:
Commercial papers: ₱1,800,000
Money market: ₱1,000,000
Time deposit (3 months): ₱800,000
Time deposit (6 months): ₱0 (original term > 3 months)

Total = ₱11,650,000

problems.scenario:
SORSOGON Company reported the following items as of December 31, 2023:

- Cash on hand: ₱2,800,000
- Cash in bank: ₱6,060,000
- Post-dated customer check included in cash on hand: ₱550,000
- Post-dated supplier check reflected in cash in bank: ₱320,000
- 2023-dated unencashed supplier check reflected in cash in bank: ₱260,000
- 2023-dated unreleased supplier check reflected in cash in bank: ₱460,000
- Petty cash (including ₱70,000 vouchers and ₱20,000 employee check): ₱200,000
- Advances to employees: ₱1,400,000
- Gift certificates: ₱80,000
- Travel fund already disbursed to marketing employees: ₱600,000
- Payroll fund not yet included in cash in bank balance: ₱1,000,000
- Bond sinking fund (restricted, liability maturing 2028): ₱3,000,000
- Investment in 5-year government bonds acquired two months before maturity: ₱2,000,000

Required: From this information, determine the amount of cash and cash equivalents.

questions.question: What is the total amount of cash and cash equivalents as of December 31, 2023?
questions.explanation:
Assumptions noted below. Calculation (summary):
Adjusted cash on hand = ₱2,800,000 - ₱550,000 (post-dated customer check) = ₱2,250,000
Adjusted cash in bank = ₱6,060,000 + ₱320,000 (post-dated supplier check added back) + ₱260,000 (unencashed supplier check added back) + ₱460,000 (unreleased supplier check added back) + ₱1,000,000 (payroll fund not yet included) = ₱8,100,000
Petty cash (included / available) = ₱200,000
Total cash = ₱2,250,000 + ₱8,100,000 + ₱200,000 = ₱10,550,000
Cash equivalents = investment near maturity ₱2,000,000
Cash and cash equivalents = ₱10,550,000 + ₱2,000,000 = ₱12,550,000

problems.scenario:
KIMBERLY Company petty cash transactions (Nov 1, 2023 to Jan 25, 2024):

- Nov 1: Established petty cash fund ₱30,000
- Nov 5: Paid ₱8,000 transportation of messengers
- Nov 12: Paid ₱10,000 office supplies
- Nov 28: Paid ₱5,000 miscellaneous expenses
- Nov 30: Replenished the petty cash fund and increased it to ₱40,000
- Dec 8: Paid ₱12,000 repair expense
- Dec 20: Paid ₱15,000 representation/treats
- Jan 10: Paid ₱11,000 transportation of messengers
- Jan 25: Petty cash replenished

Required: Prepare the journal entries using (a) the imprest fund system; and (b) the fluctuating fund system.

questions.question: Prepare the journal entries under the imprest fund system (establishment, replenishments and increases).
questions.explanation: Imprest entries: establishment and replenishments are recorded when cash is replenished or fund increased. Expenses are recorded at replenishment by debiting expense accounts and crediting cash in bank.

questions.question: Prepare the journal entries under the fluctuating fund system (record expenses when paid from the fund and replenishments).
questions.explanation: Fluctuating entries: each petty payment is recorded as expense with credit to petty cash; replenishments transfer cash from bank to petty cash.

journal_entries.description: Imprest system — Nov 1, 2023: Establish petty cash fund
Imprest system — Nov 30, 2023: Replenish and increase fund to ₱40,000 (record expenses paid from fund Nov 5, 12, 28 and increase)
Imprest system — Jan 25, 2024: Replenish to cover Dec 8, Dec 20 and Jan 10 payments
Fluctuating system — Nov 1, 2023: Establish petty cash fund
Fluctuating system — Nov 5, 2023: Payment from fund (record expense)
Fluctuating system — Nov 12, 2023: Payment from fund (record expense)
Fluctuating system — Nov 28, 2023: Payment from fund (record expense)
Fluctuating system — Nov 30, 2023: Replenish and increase fund to ₱40,000 (restore payments and add increase)
Fluctuating system — Dec 8, 2023: Payment from fund (record expense)
Fluctuating system — Dec 20, 2023: Payment from fund (record expense)
Fluctuating system — Jan 10, 2024: Payment from fund (record expense)
Fluctuating system — Jan 25, 2024: Replenish fund to restore payments
